Viruses in Distributed Systems (ENG - Master degree thesis)

Abstract

The growing reliance on distributed systems for various applications has highlighted the need to address security vulnerabilities, particularly those posed by viruses and malicious software. This thesis investigates the nature and impact of viruses in distributed systems, analyzing how these threats exploit system vulnerabilities and compromise data integrity.

The focus of this research is on identifying the mechanisms through which viruses propagate and the defensive measures that can be implemented to mitigate their impact. By examining various case studies, this thesis aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the challenges posed by viruses and the strategies that can be employed to enhance system security.

This study also evaluates the effectiveness of existing security protocols in preventing virus attacks, offering insights into potential improvements and innovations in the field of cybersecurity.

Details

The analysis begins with a review of common types of viruses and their methods of propagation. We delve into the behavior of these malicious entities within distributed environments, focusing on their ability to spread rapidly across interconnected systems.

Additionally, the thesis explores various countermeasures, including software solutions, behavioral detection, and network isolation techniques. We also assess the effectiveness of these strategies through quantitative and qualitative analysis, providing a holistic view of the current state of cybersecurity against viruses in distributed systems.

The findings highlight the importance of ongoing research and development in this area, emphasizing the need for adaptive security measures that can respond to evolving threats.
